subject: Re: [junit] How to test code generated by iContract
msgSnippet: ... Why do you want to test generated code. If the tool works, the generation works by definition. Test your own code; don t test the tool vendor s code. ... I
messageBody:
> My questions are :
> How to test the pre-processor code generated by iContract ?

Why do you want to test generated code. If the tool works, the generation
works by definition. Test your own code; don't test the tool vendor's code.

> What will be the related concerns in testing ?

I consider DBC to be an extra layer of testing. In some circumstances DBC is
a useful addition to test-driven development - especially when you deal with
public and published APIs. In other cases DBC invariants and postconditions
can overlap with unit tests and thus make one or the other superfluous. I
personally regard the DBC as superfluous in those cases since DBC
constraints are usually much weaker than unit tests: DBC constraints are not
allowed to call methods which change an object's internal state. Moreover,
DBC preconditions tell you what you don't have to test in your UTs because
there's no defined behaviour when preconditions are violated.

Johannes
